Given a positive integer $k$, find the smallest integer $n$ such that none of the first $k$ terms of the following sequence are equal to 1:

 $$n, f(n), f(f(n)), f(f(f(n))), ...$$

where 
$$f(n) = \begin{cases} 
\frac{n}{2} & \text{if } n \text{ is even} \\
3n + 1 & \text{if } n \text{ is odd}
\end{cases}$$

The integer $n$ should have at most 1000 digits.

Find the smallest number that, when repeatedly applied to itself using a specific rule, will never result in the number 1 within the first k applications. 

The rule is:

* If the number is even, divide it by 2.
* If the number is odd, multiply it by 3 and add 1. 


You are given k.
